title: Lesson 09: Dot Products and Duality
objectives: Connect dot products to linear transformations (duality)

cards.front:
How do you compute the dot product of two vectors?

\( [a, b] \cdot [c, d] = ? \)
cards.back:
Pair coordinates, multiply, and sum:

\( a \cdot c + b \cdot d \)

Example: \( [1, 2] \cdot [3, 4] = 1(3) + 2(4) = 11 \)

cards.front: What is the geometric interpretation of the dot product?
cards.back:
Geometrically, the dot product measures how much one vector points in the direction of another. Mathematically, we project one vector onto the other's line, then multiply the lengths.

\( \vec{v} \cdot \vec{w} = ||\vec{v}|| \, ||\vec{w}|| \cos(\theta) \)

where \( \theta \) is the angle between them.

Signed "alignment":
  • If θ is acute, cos(θ) > 0 ⇒ a · b > 0 (vectors point generally the same way).
  • If θ is right, cos(θ) = 0 ⇒ a · b = 0 (vectors are orthogonal).
  • If θ is obtuse, cos(θ) < 0 ⇒ a · b < 0 (vectors point generally opposite ways).

cards.front: What does the sign of a dot product tell you?
cards.back:
• Positive: vectors point in similar directions (angle < 90°)
  • Zero: vectors are perpendicular (angle = 90°)
  • Negative: vectors point in opposing directions (angle > 90°)

Yes! Order doesn't matter.

\( \vec{v} \cdot \vec{w} = \vec{w} \cdot \vec{v} \)

Projecting \( \vec{w} \) onto \( \vec{v} \) then scaling gives the same result as the reverse.

cards.front: What does it mean to dot with a unit vector?
cards.back:
It computes the projection of your vector onto the unit vector's direction.

The result is the signed length of the shadow cast onto that line.

cards.front: What is duality in the context of dot products?
cards.back:
Every linear transformation from n-dimensional space to numbers corresponds to a unique vector in that space.

Computing the transformation equals taking the dot product with that vector.

A \( 1 \times n \) matrix \( [a, b, ...] \) acting on \( \vec{v} \) gives the same result as \( [a, b, ...] \cdot \vec{v} \).
